clinical_study.official_title: Study of Verapamil in Refractory Catamenial Epilepsy

brief_summary.textblock: One in 3 epilepsy patients have refractory seizures. This drug resistance is likely related to the over expression of multidrug resistance proteins (MDR). Progesterone is a known inhibitor of MDRs and the low level of this hormone during the menstrual cycle may exacerbate seizures, perhaps explaining catamenial epilepsy; i.e. seizures occurring during the menstrual cycle. Verapamil suppresses seizures in animal models of epilepsy perhaps by inhibiting MDRs and thus may help patients with refractory seizures. If the study shows improved seizure control, the results will help establish the role of MDRs in refractory epilepsy.

clinical_study.why_stopped: protocol changed and a new study using verapamil in epilepsy will be started in the near future
clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: the percent reduction in seizure frequency

intervention.description: 80 mg daily by mouth, 5 days prior to menses for 3 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- females
- at least 2 seizures per month
- more than 50% of the seizures occur 7 days before or 7 days after the onset of menses
- patient of the Toronto Western Hospital Epilepsy Clinic
Exclusion Criteria:
- cardiovascular history
